input:

34:07 Event: Shots on target by Real
34:10 Caption: Kevin-Prince Boateng (Schalke) can't expect anything else than a yellow card for his hard tackle. And a yellow it is. Martin Atkinson doesn't think twice to pull it out of his pocket. A free kick to Real Madrid.
34:11 Caption: Cristiano Ronaldo (Real Madrid) takes the mid-range free kick and sends it towards the roof of the net, but he is denied by the goalkeeper.

35:37 Caption: Real Madrid are playing possession football and controlling the game at present. They are exchanging inch-perfect passes from player to player, making it difficult for the opposition to win the ball.

37:13 Event: Indirect free-kick by Schalke

44:29 Event: Ball out of play
44:41 Caption: An attempted cross from Cristiano Ronaldo (Real Madrid) is cleared. The referee points to the corner flag and Real Madrid will take a corner.
45:08 Event: Corner by Real
45:13 Caption: Toni Kroos (Real Madrid) takes the corner which is cleared by the opposition's defence.
45:20 Event: Shots off target by Real
45:21 Event: Ball out of play
45:30 Caption: Karim Benzema (Real Madrid) clutches his head after wasting a good opportunity. He expertly collected the ball from a rebound and fired from long range, but his effort wasn't accurate at all and the ball went miles over the crossbar. The ball is off of the pitch and it's a goal kick for Schalke.
45:54 Event: Clearance by Schalke
46:15 Event: Foul by Schalke
46:22 Event: Yellow card by Schalke
46:36 Caption: Roman Neustadter (Schalke) is awarded a yellow card for his tackle. He doesn't seem to agree with the decision, but Martin Atkinson ignores the protests. Real Madrid are given an advantage. They have a free kick.
46:59 Caption: Cristiano Ronaldo (Real Madrid) attempts to beat the goalkeeper with a powerful strike from a long-range free kick. His effort, however, goes way wide of the left post.
47:00 Event: Indirect free-kick by Real
47:01 Event: Ball out of play
47:14 Caption: There will be nothing more to see in the first half. The whistle blowing of Martin Atkinson has ended it.
47:59 Caption: We have seen a few chances and nice movements, but the overall impression of the game is rather average and not hugely entertaining. The first half was definitely edged by the visiting team. The home team's main priority is a flawless defence, while the away side's style is slow build-up play.

Second Half:
00:00 Event: Kick-off by Real
00:00 Caption: 2 min. of stoppage-time to be played.
00:01 Caption: The game restarts for the second half.
00:23 Event: Foul by Real
00:29 Caption: Isco (Real Madrid) was too forceful with his tackle and Martin Atkinson interrupted the game to signal a free kick.
00:38 Event: Indirect free-kick by Schalke

01:55 Event: Foul by Schalke

02:59 Caption: The Real Madrid players are exchanging short passes in an attempt to create a shooting opportunity.
03:14 Caption: Marcelo (Real Madrid) sends a teasing cross into the area, but Timon Wellenreuther intercepts the ball.
04:24 Caption: Dennis Aogo (Schalke) swings a cross into the box, but it's far too close to Iker Casillas, who smothers the ball.
06:20 Caption: Good clearance! Felix Platte (Schalke) received a low pass, but he didn't have time to do anything as one of the defenders quickly stole the ball off him.
06:23 Event: Ball out of play

12:40 Event: Ball out of play

17:13 Event: Foul by Schalke
17:19 Event: Yellow card by Schalke

19:19 Event: Indirect free-kick by Real
19:33 Caption: Daniel Carvajal (Real Madrid) hasn't suffered any serious injury which would see him leave the pitch. He's back in the game now.

21:02 Event: Ball out of play

22:57 Event: Ball out of play

23:47 Caption: Kevin-Prince Boateng (Schalke) produces a long-range cannon of a shot after a nice pass. The ball heads towards the middle of the goal, but is easily stopped by a save from Iker Casillas and the score remains the same.
25:43 Event: Ball out of play
25:51 Caption: The attendance is 54442.

27:52 Caption: Cristiano Ronaldo (Real Madrid) fails to produce a decent enough free kick for a player of his ability and the only target that he finds is the wall of defenders in front of him.
28:01 Event: Direct free-kick by Real
28:41 Event: Shots on target by Schalke

29:40 Event: Ball out of play

30:23 Event: Foul by Schalke

32:57 Event: Substitution by Real

34:45 Caption: Roberto Di Matteo prepares a substitution. Marco Hoger is replaced by Max Meyer (Schalke).

42:19 Event: Ball out of play
42:39 Event: Throw-in by Real
42:58 Caption: The Real Madrid players are displaying brilliant short passes and great ball movement. They are waiting to open the opposition's defence and hit them swiftly on the break.
43:33 Event: Foul by Schalke
43:35 Caption: Martin Atkinson couldn't ignore the rough tackle by Dennis Aogo (Schalke) and blew his whistle. It's a free kick to Real Madrid in a dangerous position.
43:46 Event: Indirect free-kick by Real
43:52 Event: Ball out of play
43:56 Caption: Real Madrid continue the game with a quickly taken free kick.
44:03 Event: Throw-in by Real
44:13 Event: Ball out of play
44:23 Event: Throw-in by Real
44:58 Event: Ball out of play
45:22 Caption: Marcelo (Real Madrid) attempted to create a dangerous situation in front of goal by sending a cross into the box, but the defence easily dealt with the threat.
46:58 Caption: Max Meyer (Schalke) sprays a pass out to Maxim Choupo-Moting, but he can't beat his man inside the box.
48:06 Caption: Nothing more will happen in this game as the referee blows for full time.
48:59 Caption: We were witnesses to an uneventful game without many stirring moments. There is definitely room for improvement in future games. The visitors certainly had the better of things. The home team really focused on a well-organized defence, while the away team played possession football.
    

    #######TASK 
    Provide a factually correct and detailed textual description of the game compiled from the information presented above from different sources, in more than 1000 words.
            "Cap:": represents the captions published in the online portal usually within 30 seconds of the event.
            "E:" represents events recorded exactly after the event happened.
    Don't mention sources of information like commentators or captions, write as if you saw them live.
summary:
The evening clash between Schalke 04 and Real Madrid was anticipated by fans on both sides, given the rich history and competitive spirit each team brings to the field. The game, held at the Veltins-Arena, showcased two very different playing styles, tactics, and approaches to the beautiful game, culminating in a final scoreline of Schalke 0 - 2 Real Madrid.

The match began with Schalke kicking off promptly at 00:00. However, just six seconds into the game, the ball was already out of play, leading to one of many throw-ins that would become a theme for the evening. Real Madrid took the throw-in at 00:24, quickly showing their intent to control the pace and maintain possession.

Within the first few minutes, the ball found its way out of play several times, evidencing a cautious and jittery start from both teams. Real was awarded two throw-ins (at 01:23 and 02:09) while facing an offside call against them at 03:01. Schalke responded to Real's indirect free-kick by consistently trying to push back the opposition through their own throw-ins and indirect free-kicks.

It was clear early on that physicality was going to play a significant role, with multiple fouls occurring by both sides. By the sixth minute, Real had already committed another foul, leading Schalke to take an indirect free-kick. A tense start continued to unfold with more fouls and the first yellow card issued to a Real Madrid player at 08:43 for a reckless challenge. Schalke attempted to capitalize on the ensuing free kick, but Real maintained their defensive structure efficiently.

At 10:04, Marco Hoger sent an enticing cross into the box, only for Iker Casillas to showcase his experience and agility by coming off his line to gather the ball securely. The defensive resilience of Real Madrid was beginning to shine through even though Schalke tirelessly sought out opportunities, characterized by Dennis Aogo’s free-kick at 13:23 being blocked by Real’s well-positioned defensive wall.

A pivotal moment came at 14:58 when Hoger once again threatened the Real Madrid goal by delivering a lovely cross into the penalty area, though the visitors managed to avert the danger with a brilliant clearance. Schalke, being relentless, continued their offensive efforts to no avail against Real’s resolute defence.

Real Madrid, known for their precise and deadly counter-attacks, began to showcase more of their offensive prowess. A significant incident was not long in coming when, at 17:51, some neat passing and movement led to Lucas Silva unleashing a shot that flew well wide of the left post, showcasing ambition despite the inaccurate finish.

Schalke kept pushing, with Dennis Aogo at 19:56 driving a shot high over the bar from the edge of the area, reflecting their struggle to find clinical finishing against Real's formidable defence. Real Madrid responded quickly with a few dangerous plays, including a crucial clearance by Schalke at 21:46 when Marcelo's pass was intercepted.

The game saw a significant development when, at 25:14, Daniel Carvajal produced a beautiful cross into the box toward Cristiano Ronaldo, who did not miss. Ronaldo jumped high to head the ball straight under the crossbar and beyond the goalkeeper, making it 0:1 for Real Madrid. The goal at 25:47 was not only a testament to Ronaldo's prowess but was also an indication of Real's tactical sharpness.

Despite this setback, Schalke pressed on, trying to exploit any gaps in Real Madrid’s defence. However, even their most promising efforts found formidable resistance from Real's defenders and inconvenient injuries such as the one to Klaas-Jan Huntelaar, who was later substituted by Felix Platte at 32:16.

As the game edged towards the end of the first half, Real continued to maintain control with possession and disciplined play. Karim Benzema almost doubled the lead at 30:33, but Timon Wellenreuther demonstrated excellent reflexes to keep Schalke in the game. The first half concluded with a few more attempts by Real, including a wasted opportunity by Benzema at 45:20 who fired over the crossbar, summing up a dominant first half for the visitors.

The second half commenced with Real Madrid kicking off. Isco quickly attracted attention at 00:29 with a forceful tackle that Martin Atkinson decided needed intervention. The game was characterized by Schalke's aggressive attempts to regain control and Real Madrid’s calm possession play aiming to diffuse pressure and create opportunities. Schalke’s Felix Platte displayed a high level of aggression while Real Madrid continued seeking creative routes to expand their lead.

A significant moment for Real came at 34:07 when Ronaldo attempted a powerful strike from a long-range free kick, only for it to be saved gracefully by Timon Wellenreuther. The Schalke goalkeeper was undoubtedly one of the busiest players on the pitch, consistently standing up to Real’s might.

Real Madrid’s relentless pressure paid off yet again at 33:34 when Marcelo unleashed a deadly strike from around 18 meters out, sending the ball into the top right corner to make it 0:2. Schalke’s defence had no response to the Brazilian’s brilliance.

With substitutions being made frequently in the second half, both teams refreshed their strategies and players. Schalke sought to close down the attacking threats of Real, introducing players like Jan Kirchhoff for Roman Neustadter, and Max Meyer for Marco Hoger. Real Madrid, aiming to consolidate their already strong position, substituted Karim Benzema with Chicharito, seeking to maintain fresh legs upfront.

Despite Schalke’s continued pressing and efforts, they encountered obstacles in the form of accurate interceptions and clearances by Real’s defense. Noteworthy was the attempt by Felix Platte at 28:46, which agonizingly hit the crossbar, marking Schalke’s best opportunity to get on the scoreboard.

The match wound down with Real Madrid in control, showcasing their masterful possession play and strong defensive organization. Schalke struggled to create clear-cut chances in the face of Real's technical superiority and well-prepared responses to any offensive moves.

In summation, Schalke’s strategy of a well-organized defence and Rapid counter-attacks found no fruitful end against Real Madrid’s balanced game-plan of possession football and capitalizing on carefully crafted opportunities. The game ended with Schalke 0 – 2 Real Madrid, a result that mirrored the overall control and efficiency in Real Madrid’s gameplay. The visitors left Veltins-Arena not only victorious on the scoreline but also making a strong statement of their tactical acumen and individual brilliance, whereas Schalke could take away lessons of resilience and areas requiring improvement.
